runs.text: Introduce
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this story has two different settingsthe country and the city.
Have students share what they know about each setting.
Build Vocabulary
Introduce the word perspective using the Define/Example/Ask routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
Define:
Perspective
is a way of thinking about something.
Example: Mom shared her
perspective
about how a new park would benefit the local community.
Ask: What is your
perspective
on year-round school? Are you for it or against it?
Read
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
Check Comprehension
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the sentence that tells why City Mouse wants to show Country Mouse the city. (Youll see what good living is all about!)
What is Country Mouses perspective on the city? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How are the city and country alike? How are they different?
Would you prefer to live in the city or the country? Why?
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Introduce
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this comic is about unusual homes that use nature in their designs.
Discuss how the speech bubbles show what the woman is saying, but the other text explains the images and photos.
Build Vocabulary
Introduce the word inspiration using the Define/Example/Ask routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
Define:
Inspiration
is an idea, object, or person that influences someone.
Example: A beautiful sunset was the
inspiration
for the painters artwork.
Ask: What do you do when you need to find
inspiration
for a story or art project?
Read
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
Check Comprehension
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the words in the first paragraph that reveal the narrators feelings about the homes in the text. (unusual, amazing)
What parts of nature provided inspiration for Fallingwater? Find the sentences that answer the question.
What is surprising about the homes in Cappadocia, Turkey? Explain.
Which home would you most like to live in? Why?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Focus on Target Skill
Have students circle words with the inflectional endings
-ed
and
-ing
. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Write
Have students write a sentence using the word
sitting
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss Sentence Structure
Discuss phrasing, or how to chunk longer sentences into meaningful parts.
For example, as you read sentence 4, pause briefly after lived and city.
Point out that each group of words relates to one idea in the sentence.
Have students echo your phrasing.
Explain
Read the title. Explain that this is a comic. The speech bubbles point to the character that says the words.
Remind students to read the words and study the pictures to understand what happens in the story.
Read
For the first reading, read aloud the speech bubbles and have students describe what happens in each frame.
Then pair students to alternate rereading the speech bubbles.
Prompt
Prompt students to find all of the words with
-ed
and
-ing
endings and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words.
Say
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Offer Phonics Supports
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include Sound Boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Offer High-Frequency Word Supports
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
These supports include the
Read/Build/Write
routine.
Read Aloud
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
Introduce
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that students will read an informational text about the history of neighborhoods.
Have students read the photo captions to identify what each photo shows.
Build Vocabulary
Introduce the word located using the Define/Example/Ask routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
Define:
Located
means in a certain place.
Example: The library is
located
next to the post office.
Ask: Where is the grocery store
located
Read
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
Check Comprehension
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the phrase that tells the first thing you should do on a walk to learn about your neighborhood. (start noticing things)
Who should you ask if you want to know more about what your neighborhood was like long ago? Find the sentence that answers this question.
How do neighborhoods change over time? Explain.
What buildings are located in your neighborhood? What are their purposes?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Focus on Target Skill
Have students circle words with inflectional endings. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Write
Have students write a sentence using the word
baking
Have them read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss Sentence Structure

Discuss the different end punctuation for sentences 1 (period), 6 (question mark), and 9 (exclamation point). Model how you change your intonation when reading a question (raise voice at end) or exclamation (read with emotion). Then have students read the sentences consecutively.
Explain
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this map shows the buildings and streets in a neighborhood. Discuss the features of a map.
Have students point to the labels and the locations they name.
Read
Guide students through a reading of the text, including the labels on the map.
Prompt
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the map.
Introduce

Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read a letter written by a boy to his city council.
Build Vocabulary
Introduce the word value using the Define/Example/Ask routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the letter.
Define:
Value
is the
importance or worth of something.
Example: This necklace has
value
because it was a gift from Jadas grandmother.
Ask: What do you
value
the most? Why?
Read
Have students whisperread the letter. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
Check Comprehension
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the phrase that tells why the writer is upset. (the city is planning to tear down historic Hill House)
What would happen if Hill House is torn down? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Does the writer make a convincing argument? Why or why not?
Do you think that historic buildings add value to neighborhoods? Explain.
Have students reread the letter during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Introduce
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this informational text is a biography, or story about a persons life.
Have students share common features of biographies.
Build Vocabulary
Introduce the word expedition using the Define/Example/Ask routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
Define:
Expeditions
are trips with a specific purpose.
Example: Scientists go on long
expeditions
in forests around the world to discover, or find, rare plants and animals.
Ask: Would you like to go on an
expedition
to another country? Where would you go? Why?
Read
Have students whisperread the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
Check Comprehension
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the phrase that tells the purpose of Lewis and Clarks trip. (exploring new lands)
Who joined Sacagawea on the expedition? Find the sentence that answers the question.
Which details from the text support the claim that Sacagawea is famous?
Why do you think people still admire Sacagawea after hundreds of years?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
